audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a new video, planning to focus on "cell membrane or plasma membrane". His tone is educational and somewhat formal. He lists other names for this concept, such as "lipid bilayer" and "plasmalemma", describing it as "one of the important parts of a cell". He then begins to define "cell membrane or plasma membrane".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker's informative tone, introducing the importance of something, stating "let's have a look." He describes its function as separating the inside of a cell from the outside environment, acting as a wall and selectively allowing cargo to pass. He uses an airport passport control analogy to illustrate the selectivity. The speaker emphasizes the role of plasma membrane proteins as control officers, preventing unwanted elements from entering and removing bad things from the cell. He highlights the transportation of nutrients and waste by the cell, deeming it very important.

A male speaker is explaining the structure of cell membranes in a professional, informative tone, detailing the composition of lipids, proteins, and cholesterol, focusing on the layers and components like phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylserine. He mentions cholesterol's presence on both sides, referring to the inside and outside of a cell as a "wall." The speaker then shifts to discussing membrane proteins.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the composition of plasma membranes, mentioning lipids, proteins, and cholesterol. He explains that lipids form the fundamental part of the lipid bilayer, while proteins carry out membrane functions. He notes that the plasma membrane is mostly composed of 50% protein and 50% lipid by weight, with carbohydrates comprising 5 to 10% of the membrane. His tone is informative and academic.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing two scientists and stating that they "proposed the fluid mosaic model of plasma membrane in 1972." He mentions that the model is "now accepted as a basic model of all biological membrane" in a factual tone. The speaker then asks "what is about, what is fluid mosaic model?" and continues to explain that the model includes "integral membrane proteins and peripheral proteins."

The audio begins with a male speaker defining "integral proteins" and "peripheral proteins," noting their respective relationships to the cell membrane. He speaks in an informative tone. This is followed by a description of integral proteins as transmembrane proteins with portions exposed on both sides of the membrane and glycosylated outside the membrane.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a process called "glycosylation", explaining how "carbohydrate moieties are attached".  The speaking tone is informative and slightly academic.  The speaker describes a molecule, pointing to it with the words "right here", then describes a visual detail, saying "right in the blue". The speaker then asks to look at a phospholipid molecule "in a little bit in detail."

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing molecules, particularly phospholipids, noting that they are "hydrophilic as well as hydrophobic" and love and hate water simultaneously. He describes the structure of a phospholipid molecule, mentioning a hydrophilic head with a phosphate group attached to glycerol and hydrophobic tails with saturated and unsaturated fatty acids. His tone is informative and somewhat educational. He then transitions to mention proteins.

An adult male speaker describes integral proteins, noting how they are "embedded inside the membrane" and interact with the hydrophobic region of the phospholipids. He mentions how some proteins are folded. The speaking tone is informative and explanatory. The speaker then transitions to discussing the role of these proteins in cell signaling pathways and cargo transportation. He compares them to passport control officers, emphasizing their importance in controlling movement in and out of the cell. The clip concludes with the speaker introducing a discussion about diseases in the plasma membrane.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the plasma membrane, emphasizing that disruptions to its integrity can cause severe consequences. He mentions that the membrane is composed of lipids and proteins, and any damage could lead to negative outcomes. The speaker has a serious and informative tone. There's no background sound throughout this narration.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing diseases associated with membrane integrity disturbance. He mentions "high level of cholesterol in blood", diabetes, obesity, and Grave's disease, describing Grave's disease as an immune system issue leading to "overproduction of thyroid hormones" or hyperthyroidism. The speaker maintains a serious and informative tone throughout.

A single male speaker is discussing cell structure instability and its effects on erythrocytes, mentioning abnormalities and altered transport systems. He transitions to the topic of cystic fibrosis, defining it as a genetic disorder primarily affecting the lungs, but also other organs. He explains that it is caused by a mutation in genes called cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator, or CFTR. He concludes by saying that there are many diseases associated with it. His tone is informative and somewhat academic.

The audio clip features a single male speaker, delivering a presentation on the plasma membrane with an informative and slightly formal tone, stressing the importance of its integrity. He then announces the end of the presentation and invites questions, followed by a mention of the next presentation being about the cytoskeleton. The speaker concludes by expressing gratitude to the listener, suggesting they subscribe for more content on cell and molecular biology, and offers a general farewell.
